pli-tv-bu-pm:9.1: If a monk, after taking on the monks’ training and way of life, without first renouncing the training and revealing his weakness, has sexual intercourse, even with a female animal, he is expelled and excluded from the community.
pli-tv-bu-pm:10.1: If a monk, intending to steal, takes from an inhabited area or from the wilderness what has not been given to him—
pli-tv-bu-pm:10.2: the sort of stealing for which kings, having caught a thief, would beat, imprison, or banish him, saying, ‘You’re a bandit, you’re a fool, you’ve gone astray, you’re a thief’
pli-tv-bu-pm:10.3: —he too is expelled and excluded from the community.
pli-tv-bu-pm:11.1: If a monk intentionally kills a human being or seeks an instrument of death for him or praises death or incites someone to die, saying,
pli-tv-bu-pm:11.2: ‘My friend, what’s the point of this miserable and difficult life? Death is better for you than life!’—
pli-tv-bu-pm:11.3: thinking and intending thus, if he praises death in many ways or incites someone to die
pli-tv-bu-pm:11.4: —he too is expelled and excluded from the community.
pli-tv-bu-pm:12.1: If a monk falsely claims for himself a superhuman quality, a knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, saying, ‘This I know, this I see,’
pli-tv-bu-pm:12.2: but after some time—whether he is questioned or not, but having committed the offense and seeking purification—should say: ‘Not knowing I said that I know, not seeing that I see; what I said was empty and false,’ then,
pli-tv-bu-pm:12.3: except if it is due to overestimation,
pli-tv-bu-pm:12.4: he too is expelled and excluded from the community.
pli-tv-bu-pm:13.1: “Venerables, the four rules on expulsion have been recited.
pli-tv-bu-pm:13.2: If a monk commits any one of them, he is no longer part of the community of monks.
pli-tv-bu-pm:13.3: As before, so after: he’s expelled and excluded from the community.
pli-tv-bu-pm:13.4: In regard to this I ask you, ‘Are you pure in this?’
pli-tv-bu-pm:13.5: A second time I ask, ‘Are you pure in this?’
pli-tv-bu-pm:13.6: A third time I ask, ‘Are you pure in this?’
pli-tv-bu-pm:13.7: You are pure in this and therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’
pli-tv-bu-pm:13.8: The offenses entailing expulsion are finished.
pli-tv-bu-pm:14.1: Venerables, these thirteen rules on suspension come up for recitation.
pli-tv-bu-pm:15.1: Intentional emission of semen, except while dreaming, is an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bu-pm:16.1: If a monk, overcome by lust and with a distorted mind, makes physical contact with a woman—holding her hand or hair, or touching any part of her body—he commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bu-pm:17.1: If a monk, overcome by lust and with a distorted mind, speaks indecent words to a woman, as a young man might to a young woman and referring to sexual intercourse, he commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bu-pm:18.1: If a monk, overcome by lust and with a distorted mind, encourages a woman to satisfy his own desires, saying, ‘Sister, she provides the highest service who in this way satisfies one like me, who is virtuous, celibate, and of good character,’ and if it is a reference to sexual intercourse, he commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bu-pm:19.1: If a monk acts as a matchmaker, conveying a man’s intention to a woman or a woman’s intention to a man, for marriage or for an affair, even if just a brief one, he commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bu-pm:20.1: When a monk, by means of begging, builds a hut without a sponsoring owner and intended for himself, it is to be no more than twelve standard handspans long and seven wide inside.
pli-tv-bu-pm:20.2: He must have monks approve a site where no harm will be done and which has space on all sides.
pli-tv-bu-pm:20.3: If a monk, by means of begging, builds a hut on a site where harm will be done and which lacks space on all sides, or he does not have monks approve the site, or he exceeds the right size, he commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bu-pm:21.1: When a monk builds a large dwelling with a sponsoring owner and intended for himself,
pli-tv-bu-pm:21.2: he must have monks approve a site where no harm will be done and which has space on all sides.
pli-tv-bu-pm:21.3: If a monk builds a large dwelling on a site where harm will be done and which lacks space on all sides, or he does not have monks approve the site, he commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bu-pm:22.1: If a monk who is angry and displeased groundlessly charges a monk with an offense entailing expulsion, aiming to make him leave the monastic life,
pli-tv-bu-pm:22.2: and then after some time, whether he is questioned or not, it is clear that the legal issue is groundless, and he admits to his ill will, he commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bu-pm:23.1: If a monk who is angry and displeased, uses an unrelated legal issue as a pretext to charge a monk with an offense entailing expulsion, aiming to make him leave the monastic life,'
pli-tv-bu-pm:23.2: and then after some time, whether he is questioned or not, it is clear that the legal issue is unrelated and was used as a pretext, and he admits to his ill will, he commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bu-pm:24.1: If a monk pursues schism in a united Sangha or persists in taking up a legal issue conducive to schism, the monks should correct him like this,
pli-tv-bu-pm:24.2: ‘Venerable, don’t pursue schism in the united Sangha or persist in taking up a legal issue conducive to schism.
pli-tv-bu-pm:24.3: Stay with the Sangha, for a united Sangha—in concord, in harmony, having a joint recitation—is at ease.’
pli-tv-bu-pm:24.4: If that monk continues as before, the monks should press him up to three times to make him stop.
pli-tv-bu-pm:24.5: If he then stops, all is well.
pli-tv-bu-pm:24.6: he commits an offense entailing suspension.

pli-tv-bu-pm:25.3: He speaks in accordance with the Teaching and the training.
pli-tv-bu-pm:25.4: And he speaks with our consent and approval. He knows about us and speaks for us, and we approve of this.”
pli-tv-bu-pm:25.5: The monks should correct those monks like this:

pli-tv-bu-pm:25.8: And don’t consent to schism in the Sangha.
pli-tv-bu-pm:25.9: Stay with the Sangha, for a united Sangha—in concord, in harmony, having a joint recitation—is at ease.'
pli-tv-bu-pm:25.10: If those monks still continue as before, the monks should press them up to three times to make them stop.
pli-tv-bu-pm:25.11: If they then stops, all is well.
pli-tv-bu-pm:25.12: they commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bu-pm:26.1: If a monk is difficult to correct, and he makes himself incorrigible when legitimately corrected by the monks concerning the training rules that are recited, saying,
pli-tv-bu-pm:26.2: “Venerables, don’t say anything to me, either good or bad, and I won’t say anything to you, either good or bad.
pli-tv-bu-pm:26.4: then the monks should correct him like this:
pli-tv-bu-pm:26.5: 'Be easy to correct, Venerable, not incorrigible.
pli-tv-bu-pm:26.6: And please give legitimate correction to the monks, and the monks will do the same to you.
pli-tv-bu-pm:26.7: For it’s in this way that the Buddha’s community has grown, that is, through mutual correction and mutual clearing of offenses.'

pli-tv-bu-pm:27.1: If a monk who lives supported by a village or town is a corrupter of families and badly behaved, and his bad behavior has been seen and heard about, and the families corrupted by his have been seen and heard about,

pli-tv-bu-pm:27.3: 'Venerable, you’re a corrupter of families and badly behaved. Your bad behavior has been seen and heard about, and the families corrupted by you have been seen and heard about. Leave this monastery; you’ve stayed here long enough.'
